description: Those looking to complete the Cisco Certified Network Associate (CCNA) Security certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the Implementing Cisco IOS Network Security (IINS) exam required to pass in order to receive the certification. CCNA Security addresses how to properly secure Cisco devices and security on Cisco routers and switches and is designed not just for IT professionals, but also for any kind of network administrator that supports Cisco equipment. The exam objectives cover a wide range of topics including common security threats, iOS ACLs, Cisco firewall technologies and others, which can provide foundational knowledge for achieving further related certifications like the CCNP.
name: CCNA Security 640-554
subtitle: Cisco Certified Network Associate Security

episodes.description: The CCNA certification addresses security when it comes to dealing with Cisco devices and networks and to achieve it, one will first need to have already achieved the CCENT certification as a prerequisite. Viewers will hear an overview about the knowledge one needs to attain the CCNA certification, the Implementing Cisco IOS Network Security (IINS) exam that covers in-depth technical concepts and hear about the exam objectives for implementing Cisco IOS network security.
episodes.title: Overview of CCNA Security
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,082
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,082 --> 00:00:11,878
The CCNA Security certification
is one of the specializations for

3
00:00:11,878 --> 00:00:15,220
the Cisco certified network associate.

4
00:00:15,220 --> 00:00:19,010
The CCA security specifically
addresses well, security.

5
00:00:19,010 --> 00:00:22,220
How improperly secure our Cisco device is.

6
00:00:22,220 --> 00:00:25,730
And it doesn't just focus on
security only devices right.

7
00:00:25,730 --> 00:00:27,100
When we think of security,

8
00:00:27,100 --> 00:00:30,900
in my mind I immediately think of
Cisco's adaptive security appliances.

9
00:00:30,900 --> 00:00:33,140
They're ASA firewalls, right?

10
00:00:33,140 --> 00:00:36,750
And those are covered right
here on the CCNA Security, but

11
00:00:36,750 --> 00:00:41,240
we also take a look at security
on Cisco routers and switches.

12
00:00:41,240 --> 00:00:44,790
You've got to understand, that security
is not applied at just one place.

13
00:00:44,790 --> 00:00:48,590
Cisco always recommends what's called
the defense in depth security procedure,

14
00:00:48,590 --> 00:00:52,730
and that means that we've got a security
implemented all throughout our network.

15
00:00:52,730 --> 00:00:55,260
Your routers and your switches
actually make very attractive

16
00:00:55,260 --> 00:00:58,600
targets to attackers trying to
compromise your systems and so

17
00:00:58,600 --> 00:01:00,860
we've got to take proper
security measures there.

18
00:01:00,860 --> 00:01:03,570
So while there certainly is
a lot of work on firewalls,

19
00:01:03,570 --> 00:01:05,960
there's also work on routers and
switches too.

20
00:01:05,960 --> 00:01:10,140
The CCNA Security does a great
job of addressing all of that.

21
00:01:10,140 --> 00:01:13,880
Now, the CCNA Security is one of those
certifications that I think is pretty neat

22
00:01:13,880 --> 00:01:19,160
because it's not catered to
just IT security professionals.

23
00:01:19,160 --> 00:01:22,870
If you are any kind of network
administrator that supports Cisco

24
00:01:22,870 --> 00:01:27,500
equipment, I think the CCNA Security
certification is a great one to pursue

25
00:01:27,500 --> 00:01:31,150
because security is something
that everyone performs,

26
00:01:31,150 --> 00:01:33,070
not just the security IT officers.

27
00:01:33,070 --> 00:01:35,060
It's really something that everybody does.

28
00:01:35,060 --> 00:01:38,690
So we all play our part in having a basic
understanding of what's available

29
00:01:38,690 --> 00:01:40,090
is really important.

30
00:01:40,090 --> 00:01:44,150
One of the neat things that I usually hear
from viewers that have watched the show

31
00:01:44,150 --> 00:01:48,390
is they'll say, man, I never knew some
of these features were there, and

32
00:01:48,390 --> 00:01:50,610
that's the sad part of all this.

33
00:01:50,610 --> 00:01:55,120
Cisco equipment has so many powerful
security features built into it, but

34
00:01:55,120 --> 00:01:59,550
they turn them off by default because
they don't know if people need them or

35
00:01:59,550 --> 00:02:00,960
know how to use them.

36
00:02:00,960 --> 00:02:03,850
If you improperly deploy some of the
security measures it can cause all sorts

37
00:02:03,850 --> 00:02:04,770
of problems.

38
00:02:04,770 --> 00:02:09,240
So, these features are turned off when
you get a router out of the box or

39
00:02:09,240 --> 00:02:12,490
get a firewall out of the box, and
all you have to do is turn them on and

40
00:02:12,490 --> 00:02:16,040
you can increase the security on your
network very, very, very greatly and

41
00:02:16,040 --> 00:02:20,600
you can completely eliminate some of the
very common threats that are out there.

42
00:02:20,600 --> 00:02:23,190
And things that companies
still fall victim to today.

43
00:02:23,190 --> 00:02:27,472
So, it's a great certification,
covers a lot of wonderful knowledge.

44
00:02:27,472 --> 00:02:31,630
All right, let's talk a little bit about
the exam, and what we need to understand.

45
00:02:31,630 --> 00:02:36,680
The CCNA itself is a mid tier
certification, it's above the CCENT,

46
00:02:36,680 --> 00:02:41,960
but not at the level of the Cisco
Certified Network Professional, the CCNP.

47
00:02:41,960 --> 00:02:44,095
But, it is a specialization.

48
00:02:44,095 --> 00:02:48,070
There's the CCNA routing and switching
that a lot of people pursue that focuses

49
00:02:48,070 --> 00:02:50,850
on routers and switches,
but this one is security.

50
00:02:50,850 --> 00:02:54,185
It covers routers and switches also,
but not from the routing perspective.

51
00:02:54,185 --> 00:02:55,725
From the security perspective.

52
00:02:56,835 --> 00:02:59,485
The certification does just have one exam.

53
00:02:59,485 --> 00:03:01,305
But that's a little bit misleading,

54
00:03:01,305 --> 00:03:06,865
because you actually have to have
the CCENT certification first.

55
00:03:06,865 --> 00:03:10,085
You need to have the CCENT
before you can move on and

56
00:03:10,085 --> 00:03:12,830
get the CCNA security certification.

57
00:03:12,830 --> 00:03:17,020
So first you'll have to do
100-101 exam to get your CCENT.

58
00:03:17,020 --> 00:03:23,340
Then you can do the 640-554 IINS exam.

59
00:03:23,340 --> 00:03:28,040
IINS somewhat cryptically stands for
Implementing Cisco IOS Network Security.

60
00:03:28,040 --> 00:03:31,810
And in the earlier days in some of
the older versions of the certification,

61
00:03:31,810 --> 00:03:37,840
it focused just on the IOS, so
you had Cisco routers and switches.

62
00:03:37,840 --> 00:03:42,440
But in the newer versions like
the 640-554, it goes beyond IOS and

63
00:03:42,440 --> 00:03:44,550
covers the ASA's also.

64
00:03:44,550 --> 00:03:47,370
So you do have Cisco firewall
configurations to be found in there too.

65
00:03:48,500 --> 00:03:50,500
It's all great knowledge to have, and

66
00:03:50,500 --> 00:03:54,920
definitely something useful for really
anybody who works for Cisco equipment.

67
00:03:56,000 --> 00:03:58,250
Now the exam itself, it's 90 minutes, so

68
00:03:58,250 --> 00:04:02,150
you have a little bit more time
than most of the Cisco exams.

69
00:04:02,150 --> 00:04:04,265
And it's 55 to 65 questions.

70
00:04:04,265 --> 00:04:06,680
That's about three minutes per question.

71
00:04:06,680 --> 00:04:08,150
Sorry, it's about two
minutes per question.

72
00:04:08,150 --> 00:04:08,920
There we go.

73
00:04:08,920 --> 00:04:11,190
Which is a decent amount of time.

74
00:04:11,190 --> 00:04:15,230
There are some simulation questions on
the exam, but it's not as heavy as some of

75
00:04:15,230 --> 00:04:19,110
the others and you'll have some
graphical simulation questions because

76
00:04:19,110 --> 00:04:23,150
the Cisco ASA's are administered
with a Graphical User Interface.

77
00:04:23,150 --> 00:04:24,910
They can be done with a command line.

78
00:04:24,910 --> 00:04:27,100
But Cisco doesn't expect you
to use that on the exam.

79
00:04:28,240 --> 00:04:30,270
The exam is proctored through Pierson Vue.

80
00:04:30,270 --> 00:04:33,630
So when you're ready to take it,
you go to the Pierson Vue website.

81
00:04:33,630 --> 00:04:36,800
It's www.piersonvue.com, and

82
00:04:36,800 --> 00:04:42,199
remember Vue is spelled Vue,
so piersonvue.com/cisco.

83
00:04:42,199 --> 00:04:45,920
On that page, you'll be able to
find a testing center near you, so

84
00:04:45,920 --> 00:04:48,200
it's usually a convenient location nearby.

85
00:04:48,200 --> 00:04:51,500
They have offices all over the world, so
it doesn't even matter what country you're

86
00:04:51,500 --> 00:04:54,300
in, you can usually find one within
a reasonable driving distance.

87
00:04:55,360 --> 00:04:58,620
You can schedule you're exam with them,
pay them to take the exam.

88
00:04:58,620 --> 00:04:59,890
And then you go and take it.

89
00:04:59,890 --> 00:05:04,160
And when you pass you'll receive
your CCNA Security Designation.

90
00:05:04,160 --> 00:05:07,330
Now, you'll find out immediately
upon completing the exam whether you

91
00:05:07,330 --> 00:05:08,560
pass or fail.

92
00:05:08,560 --> 00:05:11,170
If you pass, great,
you get your certification.

93
00:05:11,170 --> 00:05:14,200
You'll get a certificate in
the mail a few weeks later.

94
00:05:14,200 --> 00:05:17,280
If you don't pass the first time,
you can retake it.

95
00:05:17,280 --> 00:05:19,550
It's not just a one shot attempt thing.

96
00:05:19,550 --> 00:05:20,780
You can always retake it again.

97
00:05:20,780 --> 00:05:23,970
They just ask that you wait five
calendar days before taking it again.

98
00:05:23,970 --> 00:05:26,460
So they create a bit of
a delay between retakes.

99
00:05:26,460 --> 00:05:31,650
All right, the exam objectives
cover a wide range of topics.

100
00:05:31,650 --> 00:05:35,310
And if you've compared these to
other certification exams from Cisco

101
00:05:35,310 --> 00:05:36,990
there's a lot more areas here.

102
00:05:36,990 --> 00:05:40,530
So, it really is a smorgasboard of topics

103
00:05:40,530 --> 00:05:42,590
kind of spread across all
the different equipment.

104
00:05:42,590 --> 00:05:43,670
Let's look at those objectives here.

105
00:05:45,210 --> 00:05:48,960
All right, so
we start off with common security threats.

106
00:05:48,960 --> 00:05:50,670
This isn't really unique to Cisco,

107
00:05:50,670 --> 00:05:53,910
these are just the primary security
threats that are out there.

108
00:05:53,910 --> 00:05:55,540
If you're gonna protect your network,

109
00:05:55,540 --> 00:05:57,570
you'd need to know what
you're protecting it from.

110
00:05:57,570 --> 00:06:00,110
And so we'll talk about some of the
different things that are out there that

111
00:06:00,110 --> 00:06:02,370
people can use to try and
gain access to your systems.

112
00:06:03,390 --> 00:06:06,070
Then we'll start looking
at how to fix that.

113
00:06:06,070 --> 00:06:09,150
So the first section is really
kind of like a scare section,

114
00:06:09,150 --> 00:06:11,000
get you all worried
about what's out there.

115
00:06:11,000 --> 00:06:14,370
And then all of the other modules
talk about how we can prevent that

116
00:06:14,370 --> 00:06:15,550
from happening.

117
00:06:15,550 --> 00:06:17,990
In 2.0 we look at Cisco routers.

118
00:06:17,990 --> 00:06:21,520
Your Cisco iOS routers have a lot of
security functionality in there that you

119
00:06:21,520 --> 00:06:23,790
can configure and
enable to protect your network.

120
00:06:23,790 --> 00:06:25,800
So we'll see what they can do.

121
00:06:25,800 --> 00:06:26,630
Triple A.

122
00:06:26,630 --> 00:06:30,210
That's authentication,
authorization, and accounting.

123
00:06:30,210 --> 00:06:33,980
That's how we can provide user
authentication on our routers, switches,

124
00:06:33,980 --> 00:06:36,590
firewalls, VPN for remote access.

125
00:06:36,590 --> 00:06:39,360
So that everybody can have their
own individual user accounts,

126
00:06:39,360 --> 00:06:40,750
instead of sharing them.

127
00:06:40,750 --> 00:06:42,180
We authenticate them.

128
00:06:42,180 --> 00:06:44,670
We authorize them,
figure out what they're allowed to do.

129
00:06:44,670 --> 00:06:47,420
And then we do accounting we
record what they've done.

130
00:06:47,420 --> 00:06:48,250
We keep a record.

131
00:06:49,420 --> 00:06:52,500
Then we move into access control lists or
ACLs.

132
00:06:52,500 --> 00:06:55,060
Now if you've already got
your CCNA routing and

133
00:06:55,060 --> 00:06:58,240
switching certification you probably
learned ACL's for routers already, so

134
00:06:58,240 --> 00:07:03,040
there's some overlap there, but
we also focus on ACLs on Cisco ASAs.

135
00:07:03,040 --> 00:07:07,000
And the access control lists are a little
bit different on the ASAs because they're

136
00:07:07,000 --> 00:07:10,260
stateful firewalls, they behave
a little different than routers, so

137
00:07:10,260 --> 00:07:12,650
it's a good chance to see how they work,
and how to configure them.

138
00:07:13,790 --> 00:07:17,580
Then we go into secure network
management and reporting.

139
00:07:17,580 --> 00:07:20,540
We need to be able to
evaluate our systems and

140
00:07:20,540 --> 00:07:23,560
determine when a compromise has
happened or determine when there's

141
00:07:23,560 --> 00:07:26,600
unauthorized activity on the network so
you can take action to prevent it.

142
00:07:28,140 --> 00:07:31,730
Now up here we looked at common security
threats to the network as a whole, but

143
00:07:31,730 --> 00:07:36,090
in objective six we look at take a look
at layer two attacks specifically.

144
00:07:36,090 --> 00:07:39,000
A lot of people neglect
to secure their switches.

145
00:07:39,000 --> 00:07:42,600
And switches can be very vulnerable
to certain types of attacks, and

146
00:07:42,600 --> 00:07:44,370
are pretty easy to pull off.

147
00:07:44,370 --> 00:07:47,820
Cisco switches have built in
mechanisms that protect from those, but

148
00:07:47,820 --> 00:07:50,380
the majority of them are turned
off out of the box, so

149
00:07:50,380 --> 00:07:52,460
we've got to get those configured and
enabled.

150
00:07:52,460 --> 00:07:55,860
But we need to understand how they
work before we turn them on, and

151
00:07:55,860 --> 00:07:57,420
that's what that section is all about.

152
00:07:58,490 --> 00:08:01,110
Module seven is all about
Cisco Firewall Technologies.

153
00:08:01,110 --> 00:08:04,290
The Cisco adaptive security appliances or
ASAs.

154
00:08:04,290 --> 00:08:07,920
If you've never worked with an ASA,
this will be your introduction.

155
00:08:07,920 --> 00:08:10,740
You'll get a chance to see what an ASA is,
the different models,

156
00:08:10,740 --> 00:08:13,860
how they work,
the user interface for the ASAs and

157
00:08:13,860 --> 00:08:16,990
that introduction to
deploying them on a network.

158
00:08:16,990 --> 00:08:20,240
Now it is a fairly simple
ASA configuration here.

159
00:08:20,240 --> 00:08:23,900
For those of you that go on to do
the CCNP security, the higher level,

160
00:08:23,900 --> 00:08:28,210
there is a dedicated certification
exam just to the ASA's,

161
00:08:28,210 --> 00:08:29,870
very focused and goes very in depth.

162
00:08:31,020 --> 00:08:34,900
The same thing goes for CISCO IPS or
Intrusion Prevention Systems.

163
00:08:34,900 --> 00:08:38,530
With Cisco IPS we learn about some of the
different ways that they're available as

164
00:08:38,530 --> 00:08:43,620
dedicated appliances like the 4200 Series
and we look at the embedded appliances,

165
00:08:43,620 --> 00:08:47,200
the ones that go inside of the big
Cisco switches or inside of the ASAs.

166
00:08:47,200 --> 00:08:49,150
We get a chance to see how they work, but

167
00:08:49,150 --> 00:08:53,020
just like the ASAs up here,
it is a fairly cursory overview.

168
00:08:53,020 --> 00:08:54,940
We get a chance to see
how the IPSs work and

169
00:08:54,940 --> 00:08:59,370
what they do, But for those of you
that go onto the CCNP security level,

170
00:08:59,370 --> 00:09:02,050
there's a dedicated exam just for
the IPS's.

171
00:09:02,050 --> 00:09:04,230
It goes very in depth and very thorough.

172
00:09:05,750 --> 00:09:10,040
And then lastly in module nine
we tackle VPN technologies.

173
00:09:10,040 --> 00:09:14,530
In that final objective we're looking
at the different types of virtual

174
00:09:14,530 --> 00:09:18,380
private networks that we can build,
the security ramifications for each,

175
00:09:18,380 --> 00:09:20,260
which ones are better in which scenarios.

176
00:09:20,260 --> 00:09:24,100
And how to configure them,
either between Cisco IOS routers or

177
00:09:24,100 --> 00:09:28,810
between Cisco ASAs, and how we choose
which of those is even appropriate.

178
00:09:28,810 --> 00:09:30,760
So we get a good primer on that.

179
00:09:30,760 --> 00:09:34,465
I know we talk about VPNs in some of
the other certifications, but in the Cisco

180
00:09:34,465 --> 00:09:38,341
kind of certification path, this is really
the first time that we get in there and

181
00:09:38,341 --> 00:09:41,970
configure them and
actually work with the VPN tunnels.

182
00:09:41,970 --> 00:09:45,070
Now, all of this is great
knowledge to have for

183
00:09:45,070 --> 00:09:47,280
anybody who works with Cisco equipment.

184
00:09:47,280 --> 00:09:50,050
Regardless of whether you're
a security tech or not.

185
00:09:50,050 --> 00:09:53,190
I find this as a really
rewarding certification.

186
00:09:53,190 --> 00:09:58,110
And the exam Is actually not that bad,
compared to some of the other Cisco exams.

187
00:09:58,110 --> 00:10:00,610
I don't wanna say it's easy,
cuz none of them are easy.

188
00:10:00,610 --> 00:10:03,270
But this one's a little bit
less challenging because

189
00:10:03,270 --> 00:10:06,770
the topics have a bit of
overlap with the CCNA,

190
00:10:06,770 --> 00:10:09,010
if you've already done the routing and
switching side.

191
00:10:09,010 --> 00:10:10,980
And some of it's common sense.

192
00:10:10,980 --> 00:10:12,490
So you just need to know the technologies,

193
00:10:12,490 --> 00:10:14,380
and you're able to deploy
them pretty straightforward.

194
00:10:14,380 --> 00:10:18,300
So it's a good examination, and
one that a lot of people do enjoy.

195
00:10:19,542 --> 00:10:23,680
All right, so, that's basically
what the CCNA security is,

196
00:10:23,680 --> 00:10:25,750
and that's pretty much that.

197
00:10:25,750 --> 00:10:29,880
So, if that sounds like something you
want to learn, those are the topics that

198
00:10:29,880 --> 00:10:31,890
you're interested in,
then you're in the right place.

199
00:10:31,890 --> 00:10:34,500
Stay tuned,
we're going to be jumping into that next.

200
00:10:34,500 --> 00:10:36,740
If that doesn't sound right for
you, if you were looking for

201
00:10:36,740 --> 00:10:39,770
something specifically for ASAs or IPSs or

202
00:10:39,770 --> 00:10:43,420
whatever then you may need to check
out some of the other certifications.

203
00:10:43,420 --> 00:10:45,360
Check the ITProTV library, right?

204
00:10:45,360 --> 00:10:48,090
All the certifications we cover
are part of your subscription.

205
00:10:48,090 --> 00:10:49,440
We don't charge per cert.

206
00:10:49,440 --> 00:10:52,530
So you can jump over and
check those out if we have them.

207
00:10:52,530 --> 00:10:54,570
If we don't,
you might be needing to look for

208
00:10:54,570 --> 00:10:57,720
some of the more official training
that's out there from Cisco.

209
00:10:57,720 --> 00:10:59,210
Take advantage of whatever's
available to you.

210
00:10:59,210 --> 00:11:02,207
There's a ton of opportunities out there,
but for

211
00:11:02,207 --> 00:11:06,332
those of you looking to do CCNA security,
well, let's get started.

212

00:05:06,700 --> 00:05:09,930

So when we build an ACL,

Not actual command line syntax or

00:06:17,010 --> 00:06:19,450
These are the things

00:06:19,450 --> 00:06:21,340
I want to deny certain things.

108
00:06:21,340 --> 00:06:22,760
I want to permit things.

109
00:06:22,760 --> 00:06:23,790
All right?

110
00:06:23,790 --> 00:06:27,230
Each of these little entries here that I
just made would be considered an access

00:06:27,230 --> 00:06:33,900
control entry and all three of them

112
00:06:33,900 --> 00:06:38,780
We write up a list like this and then we
attach it to an interface on our router.

00:06:38,780 --> 00:06:42,170
And then the traffic that goes through
the router gets the supply to it.

114
00:06:42,170 --> 00:06:45,320
>> Yeah, so when we break down the idea

00:06:45,320 --> 00:06:46,580
There's gonna be two parts to it.

00:06:46,580 --> 00:06:49,930
We're gonna be able to actually

00:06:49,930 --> 00:06:51,270

00:06:51,270 --> 00:06:55,150
But then we also need to take that list
and now apply it to the interface that

00:06:55,150 --> 00:06:57,890

00:06:57,890 --> 00:07:00,880
Whether we're talking about incoming or
outgoing traffic as well.

121
00:07:02,280 --> 00:07:06,320
>> Now the list is applied in order.

00:07:06,320 --> 00:07:09,370
The list is applied from top to bottom.

123
00:07:09,370 --> 00:07:13,020
And so, as traffic, so let's say I
attach this to one of my interfaces.

00:07:13,020 --> 00:07:15,770
And then,
as traffic moves through that router.

00:07:15,770 --> 00:07:18,110
It says, alright,
let me take this traffic, and

00:07:20,620 --> 00:07:21,730

00:07:21,730 --> 00:07:27,305

00:07:47,710 --> 00:07:51,140

00:07:53,820 --> 00:07:55,466
It doesn't match.

00:07:55,466 --> 00:07:58,871
It just moves down to the next entry,

139
00:07:58,871 --> 00:08:03,337
Well, it is FTP traffic from Ronnie's

140
00:08:03,337 --> 00:08:07,300
And it applies and

Now, that's an important concept.

142
00:08:10,020 --> 00:08:12,270

00:08:12,270 --> 00:08:15,150
The first match is the one that applies.

00:08:15,150 --> 00:08:19,780

00:08:19,780 --> 00:08:21,600

00:08:21,600 --> 00:08:22,390

00:08:30,920 --> 00:08:32,890
We'll match that second line.

That'll apply, and

00:08:35,740 --> 00:08:36,730
That's it.

00:08:36,730 --> 00:08:41,040

So remember that for us.

00:08:42,360 --> 00:08:44,170
As the processing goes through,

00:08:44,170 --> 00:08:47,750
as traffic comes through, first match

00:09:00,560 --> 00:09:03,300
Right so, I just added line numbers to it,

Or really I should say that

00:09:07,830 --> 00:09:12,208
So let me change that.

00:09:12,208 --> 00:09:13,010
Well, that didn't work.

00:09:13,010 --> 00:09:15,032
>> [LAUGH]
>> Line entry replace all.

165
00:09:15,032 --> 00:09:15,800
There we go.

166
00:09:15,800 --> 00:09:20,080
Okay, so if we say,
deny web traffic and so on.

167
00:09:20,080 --> 00:09:24,820
What if I have web traffic destined for,
well, let's just say, for

example, web traffic destined for
Don's machine, right?

00:09:27,610 --> 00:09:31,380
Well, I've got Deny web traffic to
Ronnie's so that doesn't match.

00:09:31,380 --> 00:09:34,700
Permit FTP traffic to Ronnie,
so that doesn't match.

171
00:09:34,700 --> 00:09:37,690
Permit all traffic to Don's machine.

172
00:09:37,690 --> 00:09:40,790
Well, web traffic would be part of that,

173
00:09:40,790 --> 00:09:43,230
That would happen, and
the traffic would be permitted.

174
00:09:43,230 --> 00:09:48,050
But what if it was SSH
traffic to Ronnie's machine?

175
00:09:48,050 --> 00:09:50,770
Well, it's not gonna match the first line,
cuz it's not web traffic.

176
00:09:50,770 --> 00:09:53,086
It's not gonna match the second one,
cuz it's not FTP.

177
00:09:53,086 --> 00:09:57,590
It's not gonna match the third one,
well, it is all traffic, but

178
00:09:57,590 --> 00:09:59,390
it's not to Don's machine, right?

179
00:09:59,390 --> 00:10:01,760
This is SSH to Ronnie's machine and

180
00:10:01,760 --> 00:10:05,140
it's not gonna match the last one either,

181
00:10:05,140 --> 00:10:09,450
And so what happens is,
any traffic that doesn't match

00:10:09,450 --> 00:10:14,810
any line hits what's called

00:10:14,810 --> 00:10:17,620
That it's implied that if
you don't match the list,

00:10:17,620 --> 00:10:19,710
you must not be allowed and

00:10:20,870 --> 00:10:23,720
>> So remember that when you create an

there is always an implicit deny,

00:10:28,490 --> 00:10:32,650
when you're asked to again, verify,

Cuz if not,
that will throw you every time and

00:10:38,570 --> 00:10:39,970
that's where you'll get caught in this.

00:10:41,390 --> 00:10:45,300
>> So the reason I want to highlight

there's really two general things

So, maybe I'm tired

I'm tired of people using Telnet,

00:11:11,692 --> 00:11:16,267
I'm fed up with people using Telnet and

I don't want people using
these non-secure protocols so

I might want to write

So if I write that list like that and

I'm denying what I want to deny.

Well, everyone is going to get

you hit the implicit deny all and

So, if we're going to do a list where

And what I've got here is a switch and
a router, all right?

1058
01:01:24,010 --> 01:01:32,140
So the top part here is a- There,
that's a Cisco 37, or sorry.

1059
01:01:32,140 --> 01:01:35,810
Shoot I'm getting confused
in my head here a 3750.

1060
01:01:35,810 --> 01:01:39,530
I was right,
when I was saying it at the beginning.

1061
01:01:39,530 --> 01:01:44,380
So it's a Cisco 3750 switch,
which is a current gen switch and

1062
01:01:44,380 --> 01:01:45,221
it's a 48 port switch, all right?

1063
01:01:46,730 --> 01:01:52,480
And attached to it,
I've got a Cisco 2901 Router just a 2900.

1064
01:01:52,480 --> 01:01:59,670
And I've got a network jack running from
the router into the switch, all right?

1065
01:01:59,670 --> 01:02:04,650
If a 3750 is configured by default,
any PCs that I plug

1066
01:02:04,650 --> 01:02:09,510
into it will all be able to see
the router, by passing through

1067
01:02:09,510 --> 01:02:13,940
the switch across the uplink and into
the router and off they go, all right?

1068
01:02:13,940 --> 01:02:17,350
They will also be able to see each other.

1069
01:02:18,720 --> 01:02:20,000
So, they can see each other and

1070
01:02:20,000 --> 01:02:25,500
communicate as well as communicating
across to the router, all right?

1071
01:02:25,500 --> 01:02:29,900
Now if this is private equipment
that we own, it's all our systems,

1072
01:02:29,900 --> 01:02:32,210
that may be what we want, all right?

1073
01:02:32,210 --> 01:02:34,290
But, what if this is a DMZ?

1074
01:02:34,290 --> 01:02:37,140
What if this is a secured network?

1075
01:02:37,140 --> 01:02:41,070
And a hacker breaks into
one of these systems.

1076
01:02:41,070 --> 01:02:43,640
So the hacker comes in from the internet,
and

1077
01:02:43,640 --> 01:02:46,230
they compromise this system right here.

1078
01:02:46,230 --> 01:02:51,600
From that system,
they can now leapfrog to access all of

1079
01:02:51,600 --> 01:02:56,370
these other systems in the DMZ potentially
compromising my entire network, right?

1080
01:02:57,940 --> 01:03:02,520
That's one scenario where the default
configuration on that switch is not

1081
01:03:02,520 --> 01:03:03,730
a good thing, right?

1082
01:03:03,730 --> 01:03:05,440
Not a good layout for us.

1083
01:03:06,580 --> 01:03:10,020
The other scenario is what if
I'm a service provider, and

1084
01:03:10,020 --> 01:03:15,220
what if I have customer number one,
plugged in here?

1085
01:03:15,220 --> 01:03:20,240
Customer number two here, customer number
three here, customer number four here.

1086
01:03:20,240 --> 01:03:23,610
If I have four different customers,
I probably want

1087
01:03:23,610 --> 01:03:27,020
all four customers to be able to get to
the router to get out to the internet.

1088
01:03:27,020 --> 01:03:31,500
But, I probably don't want the customers
to see each other, all right?

1089
01:03:31,500 --> 01:03:33,810
I can write IP ACLs to filter it.

1090
01:03:33,810 --> 01:03:35,760
But what if they spoof their IP addresses?

1091
01:03:35,760 --> 01:03:37,690
They can be a real problem, right?

1092
01:03:37,690 --> 01:03:40,900
So, if I want the utmost security,

1093
01:03:40,900 --> 01:03:46,060
I need to filter based on their ports,
not their IPs, or whatever.

1094
01:03:46,060 --> 01:03:50,700
So, on most Cisco switches, we can
create what's called a private VLAN.

1095
01:03:50,700 --> 01:03:54,738
A private VLAN, is one where we
control the access based on ports.

1096
01:03:54,738 --> 01:03:57,444
>> Yeah.
>> And you're basically creating an ACL

1097
01:03:57,444 --> 01:03:58,527
for the ports.

1098
01:03:58,527 --> 01:04:03,217
The way it works, is you designate
what's called a primary VLAN.

1099
01:04:03,217 --> 01:04:06,118
A VLAN that all these ports are in.

1100
01:04:06,118 --> 01:04:08,997
Then you designate each port,

1101
01:04:08,997 --> 01:04:14,800
as being either a host port,
or a promiscuous port.

1102
01:04:14,800 --> 01:04:18,840
A host port can only talk
to promiscuous ports, and

1103
01:04:18,840 --> 01:04:20,930
a promiscuous port can talk to everybody.

1104
01:04:20,930 --> 01:04:27,480
So what we would do,
is we would flag each of these ports

1105
01:04:27,480 --> 01:04:34,010
as host ports, and then, we would
flag this port as a promiscuous port.

1106
01:04:34,010 --> 01:04:37,790
And that, would make it where all of
my customers could see the Internet

1107
01:04:37,790 --> 01:04:42,710
connection, and receive traffic,
but they couldn't see each other.

1108
01:04:42,710 --> 01:04:46,060
So if this guy tried to get
the the Internet, that would work fine.

1109
01:04:46,060 --> 01:04:51,060
If he tried to get to this other host,
that would be blocked.

1110
01:04:51,060 --> 01:04:52,630
That's perfect.

1111
01:04:52,630 --> 01:04:58,230
If I'm trying to stop a hacker from
leapfrogging between my DMZ systems,

1112
01:04:58,230 --> 01:05:00,650
or if I'm trying to keep customers
isolated from each other,

1113
01:05:02,000 --> 01:05:04,250
there's one little problem, though.

1114
01:05:04,250 --> 01:05:09,660
What if my first customer calls, and
says, hey, I need another server,

1115
01:05:10,860 --> 01:05:17,320
or, hey, I've got eight servers I want to
plug in, if I put them in a protected VLAN

1116
01:05:17,320 --> 01:05:21,220
like this, those eight servers won't be
able to see each other, where private VLAN

1117
01:05:21,220 --> 01:05:25,740
start to get complex, is when we start
designating what are called Communities.

1118
01:05:25,740 --> 01:05:29,710
A community is where I create a group of
ports, that are allowed to see each other,

1119
01:05:29,710 --> 01:05:32,320
and a promiscuous port, but
not the other customers.

1120
01:05:32,320 --> 01:05:37,180
So I could take a switch like this,
and I could break it up.

1121
01:05:37,180 --> 01:05:42,040
I could say, all right, well,
the first, what is that, 12 ports?

1122
01:05:42,040 --> 01:05:46,250
That's gonna belong to customer one, and
they'll all be able to see each other, and

1123
01:05:46,250 --> 01:05:50,630
then the next 12 ports, that's gonna
belong to customer two, and the next port,

1124
01:05:50,630 --> 01:05:54,420
that'll belong to customer three,
and then customer four.

1125
01:05:54,420 --> 01:05:57,580
So I keep going like that,
and, oh, you know what?

1126
01:05:57,580 --> 01:06:01,530
Actually I need to skip over that port,

1127
01:06:01,530 --> 01:06:07,250
because that's the one I'm going
to make the promiscuous port.

1128
01:06:07,250 --> 01:06:11,675
So I can put each of these guys
in their own community, and

1129
01:06:11,675 --> 01:06:14,235
they'll be able to see
each other just fine.

1130
01:06:14,235 --> 01:06:19,335
So one of these hosts can talk to,
you know, other hosts in the community,

1131
01:06:19,335 --> 01:06:23,165
and they'll be able to talk to
the promiscuous port to get out, but

1132
01:06:23,165 --> 01:06:26,610
they won't be able to
talk to other customers.

1133
01:06:26,610 --> 01:06:29,780
It's complex but it is effective, okay?

1134
01:06:31,040 --> 01:06:35,200
To implement it, first off, you need to
see if your switch supports it, okay?

1135
01:06:35,200 --> 01:06:37,180
And before I jump in to a real device,

1136
01:06:37,180 --> 01:06:40,910
let me just show you guys
what the syntax looks like.

1137
01:06:43,000 --> 01:06:45,415
Seems like I have an example sitting
around on one of my screens.

1138
01:06:45,415 --> 01:06:49,995
There we go, perfect.

1139
01:06:49,995 --> 01:06:54,720
So for private VLANs,
remember that promiscuous port?

1140
01:06:54,720 --> 01:06:59,500
It can send and
receive traffic from everybody, but a host

1141
01:07:01,440 --> 01:07:08,060
can only send and
receive traffic from promiscuous ports.

1142
01:07:08,060 --> 01:07:12,570
And you can have more than one
promiscuous port, but you know,

1143
01:07:12,570 --> 01:07:14,080
typically you just have
one at your router.

1144
01:07:14,080 --> 01:07:17,290
If you have more than one router though,
you'd need to do more than one port.

1145
01:07:17,290 --> 01:07:20,730
Then if we start doing communities,
isolated is the default.

1146
01:07:20,730 --> 01:07:23,460
The port can only see itself and
promiscuous ports.

1147
01:07:23,460 --> 01:07:27,590
But Communities, that's where we can see
other people in our community, great for

1148
01:07:27,590 --> 01:07:29,850
customers who have more than one machine.

1149
01:07:29,850 --> 01:07:32,760
We start by creating VLANs.

1150
01:07:32,760 --> 01:07:33,870
You'll have a primary VLAN.

1151
01:07:33,870 --> 01:07:37,450
All of these guys are gonna
be in one big VLAN.

1152
01:07:37,450 --> 01:07:41,990
But then you create basically Sub-VLANs,
Sub-VLANs to identify each customer.

1153
01:07:41,990 --> 01:07:44,970
Here's one that's flagged
as an isolated VLAN.

1154
01:07:44,970 --> 01:07:49,290
Posts in this isolated VLAN, will be able
to see themselves, in promiscuous ports.

1155
01:07:49,290 --> 01:07:52,100
Here's another VLAN,
that's a community VLAN.

1156
01:07:52,100 --> 01:07:55,270
Anybody in VLAN 110, will be able to
see the other people in VLAN 110,

1157
01:07:55,270 --> 01:07:58,410
but that's a sub of VLAN 11.

1158
01:07:58,410 --> 01:08:00,406
See, how I've issued
this command right here.

1159
01:08:00,406 --> 01:08:04,731
Private-vlan association 110, 111,

1160
01:08:04,731 --> 01:08:10,250
that's tying these other two
as sub-VLANs under this one.

1161
01:08:10,250 --> 01:08:13,480
Now you might ask yourself,
why not just use different VLANs.

1162
01:08:13,480 --> 01:08:15,810
Well then, you loose that
whole promiscuous portal part,

1163
01:08:15,810 --> 01:08:19,250
where you have one host that's
shared between the VLANs.

1164
01:08:19,250 --> 01:08:20,840
This is all done a layer or two.

1165
01:08:20,840 --> 01:08:22,560
This is not layer three switching.

1166
01:08:22,560 --> 01:08:23,950
You don't need layer three.

1167
01:08:23,950 --> 01:08:26,000
You don't need routing capabilities
in your switch to do this.

1168
01:08:26,000 --> 01:08:27,560
This is all done at layer two.

1169
01:08:27,560 --> 01:08:29,170
So it's MAC address, really, filtering.

1170
01:08:29,170 --> 01:08:30,160
Or at least link layer.

1171
01:08:31,930 --> 01:08:33,760
Then we just go into our interfaces.

1172
01:08:33,760 --> 01:08:37,060
If it's the interface that
is going to be our router,

1173
01:08:37,060 --> 01:08:38,570
we would go into that interface.

1174
01:08:38,570 --> 01:08:43,340
And we would say,
switch port mode private-vlan promiscuous.

1175
01:08:43,340 --> 01:08:45,570
So now,
it's going to be able to see everything.

1176
01:08:45,570 --> 01:08:48,095
And then we assign it,
we say host association.

1177
01:08:48,095 --> 01:08:52,880
10 for the primary VLAN, oh, actually,
you know what, I did 11 up here.

1178
01:08:52,880 --> 01:08:55,490
I've got a typo in my config, there.

1179
01:08:55,490 --> 01:09:00,570
So we would say, 11 for the primary VLAN,
and then we specify our secondary VLAN.

1180
01:09:00,570 --> 01:09:04,010
And this one I'm putting in 110,
which is tied to that community.

1181
01:09:04,010 --> 01:09:06,120
But, you know, for your promiscuous port,
it doesn't really matter,

1182
01:09:06,120 --> 01:09:08,380
because it's promiscuous,
it can talk to all of them.

1183
01:09:08,380 --> 01:09:13,140
But the other ones, I took port 10,
and for its sub VLAN,

1184
01:09:13,140 --> 01:09:17,380
I tied it to 111,
which is the isolated VLAN.

1185
01:09:17,380 --> 01:09:22,900
This computer on port gigabit 5/10,
it will be able to see,

1186
01:09:22,900 --> 01:09:25,310
and talk to the router,
because it's promiscuous, and that's it.

1187
01:09:25,310 --> 01:09:27,520
It won't be able to talk to anyone else.

1188
01:09:27,520 --> 01:09:31,440
This other port though,
5/11, its sub-VLAN is 110.

1189
01:09:31,440 --> 01:09:37,122
And so it will be able to talk
to other people in sub-VLAN 110,

1190
01:09:37,122 --> 01:09:39,600
and the promiscuous port on the router,
to get out.

1191
01:09:39,600 --> 01:09:41,920
But it won't be able to talk
to this other guy here.

1192
01:09:41,920 --> 01:09:46,060
We're effectively dicing up that VLAN,
and allowing some communications,

1193
01:09:46,060 --> 01:09:47,340
and disallowing others.

1194
01:09:47,340 --> 01:09:51,530
And because it's done by physical port,
the only way to defeat this, is to go, and

1195
01:09:51,530 --> 01:09:52,690
move the cables.

1196
01:09:52,690 --> 01:09:54,470
>> Yeah.
>> So if you have good physical security,

1197
01:09:54,470 --> 01:09:58,820
this will completely isolate those hosts,
and this is a very common practice.

1198
01:10:00,010 --> 01:10:02,020
You see this, like broadband providers.

1199
01:10:02,020 --> 01:10:03,090
So if you have DSL or

1200
01:10:03,090 --> 01:10:06,090
cable, you're sharing a network
with all the other customers.

1201
01:10:06,090 --> 01:10:09,170
But you can't talk to the customers,
or at least you shouldn't be able to.

1202
01:10:09,170 --> 01:10:12,180
So they're using technologies,
just like this to prevent it.

1203
01:10:12,180 --> 01:10:15,610
All right, just remember the first step,
is to make sure, your switch supports it,

1204
01:10:15,610 --> 01:10:16,600
not every switch does.

1205
01:10:16,600 --> 01:10:19,890
To turn it on, you issue the feature,
private-vlan command.

1206
01:10:19,890 --> 01:10:20,930
It's a little tricky.

1207
01:10:20,930 --> 01:10:24,810
I told Ronnie, I'm pretty sure our
switch here doesn't support it, so

1208
01:10:24,810 --> 01:10:29,783
I remoted into our switch, and,let

1209
01:10:29,783 --> 01:10:33,750
me just get connected to this,
it's a 4506.

1210
01:10:33,750 --> 01:10:37,300
It's not a 4506e which

1211
01:10:37,300 --> 01:10:39,950
And so I went into config, and I said,

1212
01:10:39,950 --> 01:10:45,010
feature question mark, oh, the command

1213
01:10:45,010 --> 01:10:48,969
Well, that's not always true,

1214
01:10:48,969 --> 01:10:54,050
issue the feature private-VLAN command,

01:10:54,050 --> 01:10:59,880
Okay, well my switch doesn't have

01:10:59,880 --> 01:11:03,170
is turned on by default, it's already

01:11:03,170 --> 01:11:06,730
So there is a little bit of
variation from switch to switch.

1218
01:11:06,730 --> 01:11:08,560
But on this switch,
it's all ready turned on.

1219
01:11:08,560 --> 01:11:12,410
And I know it's already on, because if

1220
01:11:12,410 --> 01:11:19,740
like creating the VLANs and stuff,
if I go in, and I say, VLAN 11,

1221
01:11:19,740 --> 01:11:23,950
private VLAN primary, here it goes.

01:11:30,900 --> 01:11:35,480

1226
01:11:35,480 --> 01:11:37,290
So, just because that command isn't there,

1227
01:11:37,290 --> 01:11:38,910
doesn't necessarily mean
that it isn't gonna work.

1228
01:11:38,910 --> 01:11:40,630
So double check that on your switch.

1229
01:11:44,400 --> 01:11:47,120
Oh, I probably need to get rid of that
VLAN, or somebody is gonna ask me later,

1230
01:11:47,120 --> 01:11:48,102
why do we have VLAN 11?

01:11:48,102 --> 01:11:50,933
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I'll say, I don't know,

01:11:51,904 --> 01:11:55,723
[LAUGH] All right, so just keep that in
mind, but the configuration is fairly

1234
01:11:55,723 --> 01:11:58,960
straightforward, the hard part

1235
01:11:58,960 --> 01:12:02,465
All of this community and isolated part
and stuff, you don't necessarily need.

1236

The default is.

1237
01:12:04,276 --> 01:12:06,813
Each host can only see
the promiscuous port,

1238
01:12:06,813 --> 01:12:11,180
so if you just stop right there,
you're pretty much in business.

1239
01:12:11,180 --> 01:12:13,740
But if you want the real power,
you bring in communities and

1240
01:12:13,740 --> 01:12:16,950
that's where you can tie multiple
ports together, which is kinda

1241
01:12:16,950 --> 01:12:21,440
what I was illustrating in this example,
where we just go through and decimate.

1242
01:12:21,440 --> 01:12:23,750
These ports are all gonna
be in one community.

1243
01:12:23,750 --> 01:12:25,910
I put them all in VLAN 110,

1244
01:12:25,910 --> 01:12:29,530
is their sub VLAN,
versus other ports that might be isolated.

1245
01:12:29,530 --> 01:12:31,998
So, it gives you that best of both worlds.

1246
01:12:31,998 --> 01:12:34,960
If you wanna read more about it,

01:12:34,960 --> 01:12:38,210

It's really the same like you saw for

But they have a nice little

01:12:53,270 --> 01:12:55,480
what a isolated versus a community.

See how these guys will be able to see

That's what we're defining

01:13:02,790 --> 01:13:04,650
So, that's what they're talking about.

1257
01:13:04,650 --> 01:13:08,960
On the exam, unlikely that you would

They want you to be

The idea what is a private VLAN, what is a

and so

You do them without thought.

00:04:51,520 --> 00:04:54,440

00:04:54,440 --> 00:04:57,610

00:04:57,610 --> 00:05:01,400

00:05:02,508 --> 00:05:04,640

00:05:06,875 --> 00:05:08,540

00:05:08,540 --> 00:05:11,140

00:05:11,140 --> 00:05:15,845

00:05:15,845 --> 00:05:17,300

01:20:41,430 --> 01:20:43,879
every other VLAN is pruned off and
that's the end of it.

1442
01:20:45,020 --> 01:20:50,170
That's great if your running Cisco phones,
but what if your not running Cisco phones.

1443
01:20:50,170 --> 01:20:54,020
What if you've got PolyCom or
somebody else that.

1444
01:20:54,020 --> 01:20:58,390
Well, in that scenario
you've got to be trunking.

1445
01:20:58,390 --> 01:21:00,596
And so
you'll say switch port mode dynamic auto.

1446
01:21:00,596 --> 01:21:04,830
That will say, hey we're going to
allow this other side to negotiate and

1447
01:21:04,830 --> 01:21:08,230
build up a trunk, or you might actually
just hardest it, switchport mode trunk.

1448
01:21:08,230 --> 01:21:12,020
But you're going to allow
trunking on that interface.

1449
01:21:12,020 --> 01:21:17,750
The problem here is that a trunk by
default carries every single VLAN.

1450
01:21:17,750 --> 01:21:23,393
So we need to go one step further and
say switchport trunk allowed VLAN and

1451
01:21:23,393 --> 01:21:28,220
then specify the two VLANs,
the data VLAN and the voice VLAN.

1452
01:21:28,220 --> 01:21:29,720
It doesn't matter what
order you put them in.

1453
01:21:29,720 --> 01:21:32,450
Although, they're supposed to
be from lowest to highest.

1454
01:21:32,450 --> 01:21:36,070
So, we're just designating what we
want our data to be on, in my case,

1455
01:21:36,070 --> 01:21:39,438
I said VLAN one, and
what we want our voice to be on, VLAN 10.

1456
01:21:39,438 --> 01:21:41,960
In fact, you're not even really
designating that you're just saying,

1457
01:21:41,960 --> 01:21:42,620
these two VLAN.

1458
01:21:42,620 --> 01:21:46,960
We don't care what the traffic is,
we'll allow these two VLANs on this port,

1459
01:21:46,960 --> 01:21:51,345
effectively pruning off
all of your other VLANs.

1460
01:21:51,345 --> 01:21:55,510
So, if an attacker comes in and says, oh
look, a void phone, I know that's a trunk.

1461
01:21:55,510 --> 01:22:00,020
They can't just unplug that phone, plug
into their PC, and then do a VLAN scan.

1462
01:22:00,020 --> 01:22:00,640
It won't work.

1463
01:22:00,640 --> 01:22:03,650
They'll only see the two VLANs
that are related to that data,

1464
01:22:03,650 --> 01:22:06,610
which they would've had access to
anyway because the phone is there.

1465
01:22:06,610 --> 01:22:09,140
So it's not any less secure than normal.

1466
01:22:09,140 --> 01:22:12,750
All right, but that's the secret sauce
right there, doing that restricted port.

1467
01:22:12,750 --> 01:22:17,430
I've seen people do that even
if they have Cisco phones.

1468
01:22:17,430 --> 01:22:19,470
And there's no damage.

1469
01:22:19,470 --> 01:22:23,850
It doesn't make things worse, but
it doesn't really achieve anything either.

1470
01:22:23,850 --> 01:22:27,980
With the Cisco phones just designating
these the access and voice VLANs,

1471
01:22:27,980 --> 01:22:31,090
that knocks it out and it stops you
from having to designate the rest.

1472
01:22:31,090 --> 01:22:34,700
So this is what you use with
non Cisco phones down here.

1473
01:22:34,700 --> 01:22:36,950
Let me just add that.

1474
01:22:36,950 --> 01:22:43,291
If you use third-party phones, Right,

1475
01:22:43,291 --> 01:22:47,032
so slight variation there
in what we would do.

1476
01:22:47,032 --> 01:22:51,940
All right,
the other thing we need to talk about

1477
01:22:51,940 --> 01:22:54,680
are VLAN hopping attacks
>> Right, and

1478
01:22:54,680 --> 01:22:59,930
that's where somebody sends traffic on one
VLAN and tries to hop to another VLAN.

1479
01:22:59,930 --> 01:23:03,670
Right?
So that's not an uncommon attack either.

1480
01:23:03,670 --> 01:23:06,820
>> There's a couple of different methods
for this, but a lot of times what

1481
01:23:06,820 --> 01:23:10,760
people talk about here are things like
what they call double tagging where they

1482
01:23:10,760 --> 01:23:14,890
can actually do that and that's where they
end up putting two different VLAN tags.

1483
01:23:14,890 --> 01:23:16,640
On that same packet, and

1484
01:23:16,640 --> 01:23:21,000
then they're actually able to get to
the VLAN that they really want to get to.

1485
01:23:21,000 --> 01:23:23,990
>> What happens is,
if they pretag their packet and

1486
01:23:23,990 --> 01:23:27,330
then the switch adds another tag,
now they've got two tags.

1487
01:23:27,330 --> 01:23:32,590
When it goes to the next switch down the
line, it trims off one tag, but it'll see

1488
01:23:32,590 --> 01:23:37,770
the original tag first, and so it
basically swaps it over to another VLAN.

1489
01:23:37,770 --> 01:23:38,980
That's a problem, right?

1490
01:23:38,980 --> 01:23:41,760
Let me go to my little
Visio diagram again.

1491
01:23:42,930 --> 01:23:44,900
And, you know,
I closed my little screen writer.

1492
01:23:44,900 --> 01:23:45,960
There we go.

1493
01:23:45,960 --> 01:23:51,270
All right, so,
basically if I've already got one tag,

1494
01:23:51,270 --> 01:23:54,190
that's not what I wanted, there we go.

1495
01:23:54,190 --> 01:23:58,150
If the attacker already
tags their frame and

1496
01:23:58,150 --> 01:24:02,330
sends it to the switch,
the switch then adds a second frame.

1497
01:24:02,330 --> 01:24:05,380
But the attacker's frame is first and

1498
01:24:05,380 --> 01:24:10,050
so when that frame jumps to
the other switch it's gonna see

1499
01:24:10,050 --> 01:24:15,350
the attacker's frame first and not
the switches frame that was added second.

1500
01:24:15,350 --> 01:24:18,950
It's gonna see the attacker's frame and
move them to the other VLAN,

1501
01:24:18,950 --> 01:24:20,660
that VLAN they designated.

1502
01:24:20,660 --> 01:24:24,330
So this port might be hard set to VLAN 10.

1503
01:24:24,330 --> 01:24:29,530
But if the attacker tags
themselves as VLAN 1,

1504
01:24:29,530 --> 01:24:35,090
it comes over,
it gets VLAN 10 added as a second tag.

1505
01:24:35,090 --> 01:24:38,740
When it comes over here,
this switch sees VLAN 1.

1506
01:24:38,740 --> 01:24:40,300
And puts him onto VLAN 1.

1507
01:24:40,300 --> 01:24:46,070
Now on a negative, they just sent
traffic to a VLAN that they're not on.

1508
01:24:46,070 --> 01:24:48,940
On a positive,
they're not gonna get any replies

1509
01:24:48,940 --> 01:24:53,507
cuz their replies are gonna be on VLAN
1 and their port is fiber VLAN 10.

1510
01:24:53,507 --> 01:24:55,338
They won't be able to get a reply.

1511
01:24:55,338 --> 01:25:00,250
So that means this is a limited utility
hack, that you can only perform

1512
01:25:00,250 --> 01:25:05,080
unidirectional attacks which are typically
gonna be denial of service attacks and

1513
01:25:05,080 --> 01:25:06,680
UDP based attacks.

1514
01:25:06,680 --> 01:25:09,930
And if you've got an intrusion prevention
system in place, these should be picked up

1515
01:25:09,930 --> 01:25:14,730
very very quickly, but if you don't have
an IPS, if you don't have something like

1516
01:25:14,730 --> 01:25:18,080
that in place, those are real attacks
that can be pulled off unidirectionally.

1517
01:25:19,780 --> 01:25:22,370
Alright, so,
how do we prevent things like this?

1518
01:25:22,370 --> 01:25:26,355
Well, fortunately double tagging
is taken care of for us.

1519
01:25:26,355 --> 01:25:29,005
Cisco switches actually detect that and
stop it.

1520
01:25:29,005 --> 01:25:33,736
If they see a frame that's already tagged,
as least on an access port,

1521
01:25:33,736 --> 01:25:36,375
they expect it on a trunk, but on
an access port, if they see a frame that's

1522
01:25:36,375 --> 01:25:40,900
already tagged they don't just add
a tag they replace, they swap it out.

1523
01:25:40,900 --> 01:25:44,320
So, they say, don't trust the tag
coming from this other system.

1524
01:25:44,320 --> 01:25:48,670
Unless it's a CDP Cisco Discovered System,
it won't trust the tag and

1525
01:25:48,670 --> 01:25:49,530
it will replace it.

1526
01:25:49,530 --> 01:25:50,329
So that's good.

1527
01:25:51,400 --> 01:25:57,050
But there are still ways that we can
unintentionally create an attack.

1528
01:25:57,050 --> 01:26:02,300
Attackers may know that the native VLAN,

1529
01:26:02,300 --> 01:26:07,389
so every trunk,
if we run 802.1Q on a switch,

1530
01:26:08,430 --> 01:26:12,640
the trunk that we're building across here,
802.1Q trunking or

1531
01:26:12,640 --> 01:26:16,210
VLAN tagging is the most
popular form of trunking, and

1532
01:26:16,210 --> 01:26:19,880
it assumes that we have a native VLAN,
one VLAN that doesn't get tagged.

1533
01:26:19,880 --> 01:26:20,670
>> Right.
>> Right?

1534
01:26:20,670 --> 01:26:24,230
That will usually be VLAN 1 by default.

1535
01:26:24,230 --> 01:26:28,040
And what is the management
VLAN on a switch by default?

1536
01:26:28,040 --> 01:26:31,198
VLAN 1, so
attackers know if I can get on VLAN 1 or

1537
01:26:31,198 --> 01:26:35,830
get on this untagged VLAN then we
can pull off all sorts of attacks.

1538
01:26:35,830 --> 01:26:39,435
And one way they can do that is
Is if they can build a trunk,

1539
01:26:39,435 --> 01:26:44,945
they can start to send untagged frames on
that trunk, and it's VLAN1 traffic, right?

1540
01:26:44,945 --> 01:26:49,385
Or if they can put a corrupt
tag on their frame, and

1541
01:26:49,385 --> 01:26:53,040
they send it along,
this switch will see it as corrupt and

1542
01:26:53,040 --> 01:26:57,370
view it as untagged traffic and
trust it as being on VLAN 1, right.

1543
01:26:57,370 --> 01:26:58,970
That's one type of attack.

1544
01:26:58,970 --> 01:27:03,620
Another type of attack is one that we
cause ourselves, if we have the native

1545
01:27:03,620 --> 01:27:09,800
VLAN set to 10 over here and
the native VLAN over here set to 1.

1546
01:27:09,800 --> 01:27:13,590
Well, if traffic comes along that is

1547
01:27:13,590 --> 01:27:19,050
VLAN 10 traffic here, it doesn't get
tagged cuz that's the native VLAN.

1548
01:27:19,050 --> 01:27:22,840
It comes over here, but
on this end the native VLAN is VLAN 1.

1549
01:27:22,840 --> 01:27:26,480
And so
it effectively flips over to VLAN 1 and

1550
01:27:26,480 --> 01:27:29,320
then it gets released onto this
network on the wrong VLAN.

1551
01:27:29,320 --> 01:27:31,110
That's our mistake, right?

1552
01:27:31,110 --> 01:27:34,510
By setting not the same
native VLAN on both sides.

1553
01:27:34,510 --> 01:27:37,770
So, we can easily adjust that and
we can manage this and

1554
01:27:37,770 --> 01:27:41,020
we do it through some simple commands.

1555
01:27:41,020 --> 01:27:45,980
Basically on your trunk board,
Cisco recommends two things.

1556
01:27:45,980 --> 01:27:49,500
Number one,
manually define your native VLAN.

1557
01:27:49,500 --> 01:27:54,630
All right, the native VLAN defaults to
VLAN 1, don't leave it there, all right?

1558
01:27:54,630 --> 01:27:56,090
And that's the second part
of the recommendation.

1559
01:27:56,090 --> 01:28:01,000
Number two,
set the native VLAN to an unused number.

1560
01:28:01,000 --> 01:28:04,596
Don't set it to, you used to set it to
your highest traffic VLAN because it

1561
01:28:04,596 --> 01:28:07,787
would improve performance, but
on newer switches, they're so

1562
01:28:07,787 --> 01:28:11,346
much more advanced that it doesn't
affect performance at all anymore.

1563
01:28:11,346 --> 01:28:15,262
And so, we need to set it to an unused
VLAN, so if a hacker tries to jump to your

1564
01:28:15,262 --> 01:28:19,332
untagged VLAN, they're just jumping
onto an empty one that's got nothing.

1565
01:28:19,332 --> 01:28:21,934
I usually pick 999, right, so

1566
01:28:21,934 --> 01:28:27,540
I'll say switchport trunk native
vlan 999 on that interface.

1567
01:28:27,540 --> 01:28:31,220
Now if somebody does manage to jump to it,
there's nothing there.

1568
01:28:31,220 --> 01:28:33,420
Good luck,
have fun with your empty network.

1569
01:28:33,420 --> 01:28:36,500
I was reading on a good recommendation
as well that when you do set this native

1570
01:28:36,500 --> 01:28:39,980
VLAN, just make sure you don't
put any ports on it as well.

1571
01:28:39,980 --> 01:28:43,674
And that way even if they were able to
do something, they get into that VLAN,

1572
01:28:43,674 --> 01:28:46,210
they don't have a path to get out of.

1573
01:28:46,210 --> 01:28:47,390
That's a good idea.

1574
01:28:47,390 --> 01:28:49,510
Yeah, yeah,
if you're doing like Layer 3 switching or

1575
01:28:49,510 --> 01:28:52,240
routing, you just wouldn't
assign a VLAN interface on it.

1576
01:28:52,240 --> 01:28:53,660
It would be completely closed off.

1577
01:28:53,660 --> 01:28:55,050
It's like a black hole, right?

1578
01:28:56,380 --> 01:29:02,102
One thing I will mention is that
you'll find people out there that say,

1579
01:29:02,102 --> 01:29:09,590
well, you know what, you can actually
tell the 802.1q to tag the native VLAN.

1580
01:29:09,590 --> 01:29:13,758
You can run this command right here,
switchport trunk native vlan tag.

1581
01:29:13,758 --> 01:29:19,450
That'll tell 802.1q to tag everything,
to not do untagged traffic.

1582
01:29:19,450 --> 01:29:24,270
That command will trim off
a lot of VLAN attacks, right?

1583
01:29:24,270 --> 01:29:26,940
It'll basically kill off any untagged
VLAN attack because you won't

1584
01:29:26,940 --> 01:29:28,320
have any untagged VLANs.

1585
01:29:28,320 --> 01:29:30,880
Right.
Well, just like this command above,

1586
01:29:30,880 --> 01:29:34,870
you've got to make sure you do it
on both ends of the cable, right?

1587
01:29:34,870 --> 01:29:37,970
So this is generally something you'll
do throughout your entire environment.

1588
01:29:37,970 --> 01:29:41,970
But one thing a lot of people
don't know is that if you leave it

1589
01:29:41,970 --> 01:29:46,640
with your native VLAN being VLAN 1,
and you issue this command right here,

1590
01:29:46,640 --> 01:29:51,480
a switchboard trunk native vlan tag,
it will still leave it untagged, okay?

1591
01:29:51,480 --> 01:29:54,970
It's a little unknown thing
a lot of people aren't aware of.

1592
01:29:54,970 --> 01:29:58,310
So you need to follow that
command up with one more thing.

1593
01:29:58,310 --> 01:30:04,110
At the global prompt,
you need to say vlan dot1q tag native.

1594
01:30:04,110 --> 01:30:08,685
And that's gonna force 802.1q to tag
the native VLAN even if it is VLAN 1 and

1595
01:30:08,685 --> 01:30:12,386
even if it's been pruned off or
whatever through allowed VLANs or

1596
01:30:12,386 --> 01:30:14,289
whatever it is gonna take it off.

1597
01:30:14,289 --> 01:30:18,271
It's really a two command command,
a two step command.

1598
01:30:18,271 --> 01:30:18,874
There we go.

1599
01:30:18,874 --> 01:30:22,477
So we want to make sure that first
we designate that we want it to tag

1600
01:30:22,477 --> 01:30:25,228
the native VLAN, and
then we turn it on globally so

1601
01:30:25,228 --> 01:30:27,780
that it knows to do it across the board.

1602
01:30:27,780 --> 01:30:29,230
All right.

1603
01:30:29,230 --> 01:30:35,170
So that's another way that we can prevent
those untagged frames from jumping

1604
01:30:35,170 --> 01:30:36,230
around, all right?

1605
01:30:36,230 --> 01:30:38,010
So pretty easy to do.

1606
01:30:38,010 --> 01:30:40,455
In one,
we're just restricting what VLANs happen.

1607
01:30:40,455 --> 01:30:44,350
In another, we're saying, all right,
we know this is a vulnerable VLAN, so

1608
01:30:44,350 --> 01:30:46,249
let's swap it out with an empty VLAN.

1609
01:30:46,249 --> 01:30:47,921
All right.

1610
01:30:47,921 --> 01:30:51,660
All right, so those are a couple of ones.

1611
01:30:51,660 --> 01:30:55,210
Another one they bring up
here is private VLANs.

1612
01:30:55,210 --> 01:31:00,100
And if you haven't watched it already,
we recorded two shows on ACLs.

1613
01:31:00,100 --> 01:31:04,170
And it was in the ACL part two show that
we went into private VLANs in depth, so

1614
01:31:04,170 --> 01:31:06,460
we kind of showed how those work, so

1615
01:31:06,460 --> 01:31:10,060
we're not gonna cover them here because
we were pretty thorough last time.

1616
01:31:10,060 --> 01:31:14,525
But private VLANs are another way because
they don't use tags the same way.

1617
01:31:14,525 --> 01:31:18,140
They use an extra added layer of
security to restrict who gets where.

1618
01:31:18,140 --> 01:31:20,680
They're not suitable for LAN use.

1619
01:31:20,680 --> 01:31:24,060
They're really designed for DMZs,
right, for exposed networks.

1620
01:31:24,060 --> 01:31:29,169
All right, so the only other thing
that we really need to talk about,

1621
01:31:29,169 --> 01:31:33,133
because we kind of talked
about most of this already,

1622
01:31:33,133 --> 01:31:38,790
is that when we have VLANs, by default,
they are isolated from each other.

1623
01:31:38,790 --> 01:31:40,530
You cannot communicate between the VLANs

1624
01:31:42,110 --> 01:31:46,150
until we set up inter-VLAN routing,
all right?

1625
01:31:46,150 --> 01:31:50,370
And then we need to be aware of how we can
secure traffic passing through our VLANs,

1626
01:31:50,370 --> 01:31:54,260
right, thinking about how our traffic
moves from a source to a destination and

1627
01:31:54,260 --> 01:31:56,650
how we can restrict that traffic,
all right?

1628
01:31:56,650 --> 01:31:59,150
So let me give you guys
an example of that, and

1629
01:31:59,150 --> 01:32:01,531
I think that's the last thing that

01:32:01,531 --> 01:32:02,360
Yeah.
Sure is.

01:32:02,360 --> 01:32:04,621
So let me get back into
one of my switches here.

1632
01:32:14,320 --> 01:32:15,980
I'm gonna just make sure
that we are trunking.

1633
01:32:15,980 --> 01:32:17,059
Good.
Okay.

1634
01:32:17,059 --> 01:32:21,783
So I have a switch, and you'll notice all
the VLANs that I have, VLAN 1, 10, 20, 30,

1635
01:32:21,783 --> 01:32:24,165
40, 50 60, 70, and 999, right?

1636
01:32:24,165 --> 01:32:26,330
So I've got a bunch of VLANs
that are sitting there.

1637
01:32:26,330 --> 01:32:33,560
Well if I look at my interfaces,

1638
01:32:33,560 --> 01:32:37,020
That's my management VLAN, and that's it.

Okay.

01:32:37,560 --> 01:32:40,640
So this switch is not doing any routing.

01:32:40,640 --> 01:32:44,500
If I do a show IP route,

01:32:44,500 --> 01:32:46,685
a switch that's not routing between VLANs.

01:32:47,930 --> 01:32:51,760
But let's say that I was, that I wanted

01:32:51,760 --> 01:32:53,220
Well that's fine, but

We need to combine routing

Definitely be aware for
the switches, there's just some

1884

basic layer two technologies, a lot of

1885

Viewers will hear about different Cisco firewall technologies including different types of firewalls and see the implementation of the Cisco IOS firewall as well as the basic configuration of Cisco ASA.

29

today we are going to

30

31

32

firewall security in the Cisco world.

33

34

In all of our previous, well.

35

Most of our previous episodes,

36

Today we're gonna kind

43

some ACAs, the firewalls.

44
00:01:59,839 --> 00:02:04,171
>> For us, these two separate
products are really kind

45

again developmental
products along the way.

46

We have firewalls, and then there was
Cisco SA which was an advanced firewall.

47
00:02:12,360 --> 00:02:17,210
You have kind of the Cisco iOS which
is not kind of the most basic one, but

48
00:02:17,210 --> 00:02:20,400
kind of in between the idea
of like an ASA and

49
00:02:20,400 --> 00:02:23,140
kind of the simplest types of
firewalls that we can actually work.

50
00:02:23,140 --> 00:02:26,530
So we as CCNAs,
heading towards our security,

51
00:02:26,530 --> 00:02:30,080
we need to at least know the basic
understanding of how to configure both.

52
00:02:32,260 --> 00:02:35,630
>> So Cisco starts off with
a nice general objective for us.

53
00:02:35,630 --> 00:02:38,670
Which is basically stating, there's a
number of types of firewalls that are out

54
00:02:38,670 --> 00:02:40,680
there, let's understand the differences.

55
00:02:40,680 --> 00:02:43,120
So we've got describe
the operational strengths and

56
00:02:43,120 --> 00:02:46,710
weaknesses of the different firewall
technologies, and they just read all four.

57
00:02:47,770 --> 00:02:50,300
These are firewall technologies that
have been around a long time, right.

58
00:02:50,300 --> 00:02:54,290
None of these are new ideas, but when
you implement security on your network,

59
00:02:54,290 --> 00:02:56,450
you've got to pick between
these four things and

60
00:02:56,450 --> 00:02:59,519
figure out which is going to be the
suitable solution for your environment.

61
00:03:00,930 --> 00:03:02,890
The very first one is
probably the oldest one.

62
00:03:02,890 --> 00:03:05,190
And it's what's called a proxy firewall.

63
00:03:05,190 --> 00:03:09,160
In today's world these are fairly rare.

64
00:03:09,160 --> 00:03:12,710
Most people just have computers that
are directly connected to the Internet and

65
00:03:12,710 --> 00:03:13,480
off you go.

66
00:03:13,480 --> 00:03:15,360
And that's it.

67
00:03:15,360 --> 00:03:17,488
But in the old days, in the early days.

68
00:03:17,488 --> 00:03:21,180
In the non-routed protocol days and
things like that these were really,

69
00:03:21,180 --> 00:03:22,310
really common.

70
00:03:22,310 --> 00:03:27,250
And what you basically had was one host
on your network that was allowed to go

71
00:03:27,250 --> 00:03:31,400
out to the Internet or some other network,
but it was typically the Internet.

72
00:03:31,400 --> 00:03:33,650
This one host was allowed
to go out to the Internet.

73
00:03:33,650 --> 00:03:37,220
If anybody else on your network
wanted to go out onto the internet,

74
00:03:37,220 --> 00:03:40,270
they had to reach out and
talk to that one host.

75
00:03:40,270 --> 00:03:42,270
That one host was called a proxy.

76
00:03:42,270 --> 00:03:48,340
It would receive connections from the
inside and then on that person's behalf.

77
00:03:48,340 --> 00:03:52,620
The proxy would then go out to the
Internet and retrieve whatever document or

78
00:03:52,620 --> 00:03:54,650
page or
whatever it was that we were asking for.

79
00:03:54,650 --> 00:03:55,370
Right?

80
00:03:55,370 --> 00:03:57,530
On a positive side,

81
00:03:57,530 --> 00:04:00,650
none of your internal clients were
directly exposed to the Internet.

82
00:04:00,650 --> 00:04:04,330
The proxy server, that was the only
thing that was exposed to the Internet.

83
00:04:04,330 --> 00:04:08,470
And the other thing was, if five
people all requested the same page,

84
00:04:08,470 --> 00:04:13,530
the proxy server would get one copy of it
and then distribute it to all five people,

85
00:04:13,530 --> 00:04:18,790
so you reduced your bandwidth, which back
in the '80s and '90s, that was a big deal.

86
00:04:18,790 --> 00:04:21,235
>> Yeah, so offered a bit of better
performance at the same time.

87
00:04:21,235 --> 00:04:22,420
>> Mm-hm.

88
00:04:22,420 --> 00:04:26,420
Now, there is a, so those are good
things about a proxy, right?

89
00:04:26,420 --> 00:04:29,060
But there's bad things about a proxy,
also, right?

90
00:04:29,060 --> 00:04:35,323
The biggest bad thing, big bad thing,
whatever, the worst negative or whatever.

91
00:04:35,323 --> 00:04:36,910
There's no good phrasing for
this, is there?

92
00:04:36,910 --> 00:04:40,100
The bad things about proxies,
the reason we don't use them so

93
00:04:40,100 --> 00:04:43,490
much today,
is that they kill encrypted protocols.

94
00:04:43,490 --> 00:04:47,660
If you send an encrypted session across
the Internet, for example, like SSL.

95
00:04:47,660 --> 00:04:50,940
Your proxy server can't
do that on behalf of you.

96
00:04:50,940 --> 00:04:52,170
And so it's gonna break it.

97
00:04:52,170 --> 00:04:53,850
It just has to pass it straight through.

98
00:04:53,850 --> 00:04:56,510
Which defeats the purpose
of having a proxy.

99
00:04:56,510 --> 00:05:01,340
Well in this day and age we do
encrypted communications all the time.

100
00:05:01,340 --> 00:05:05,950
SSL, secure FTP,
VPN technologies, all that stuff.

101
00:05:05,950 --> 00:05:08,240
And it basically breaks proxies.

102
00:05:08,240 --> 00:05:11,360
There's also some applications
that won't work through a proxy,

103
00:05:11,360 --> 00:05:15,000
like a lot of UDP traffic and
stuff like that, can get hosed up.

104
00:05:15,000 --> 00:05:19,210
So, back in the old days,
the simpler days, when it was email and

105
00:05:19,210 --> 00:05:22,610
basic web traffic, proxies were great and
they worked really well,

106
00:05:22,610 --> 00:05:26,500
Today you really only see them in schools
that wanna do Internet filtering, right?

107
00:05:26,500 --> 00:05:28,860
They wanna filter what
web site people get to,

108
00:05:28,860 --> 00:05:32,110
but you really don't see
them much outside from that.

109
00:05:32,110 --> 00:05:33,070
>> Yeah.

110
00:05:33,070 --> 00:05:36,150
Our second firewall technology that we
want to look at is the idea of what

111
00:05:36,150 --> 00:05:38,380
our objectives call is packet.

112
00:05:38,380 --> 00:05:40,400
And state full packet here.

113
00:05:40,400 --> 00:05:44,140
Now on this idea you sometimes
hear it called static filtering or

114
00:05:44,140 --> 00:05:45,710
static packet filtering.

115
00:05:45,710 --> 00:05:48,880
And the idea of state full
packet filtering here.

116
00:05:48,880 --> 00:05:52,360
In the most basic idea of the firewall,
right.

117
00:05:52,360 --> 00:05:55,380
We have rules that allow us to
have data that goes inbound and

118
00:05:55,380 --> 00:05:57,430
then we can filter out the rest of it.

119
00:05:57,430 --> 00:06:01,610
With the static packet filtering it
only really looks at that information.

120
00:06:01,610 --> 00:06:03,970
It doesn't care if there's a connection or
not.

121
00:06:03,970 --> 00:06:07,320
It just says, okay, it matches this
rule according to where it's going,

122
00:06:07,320 --> 00:06:09,430
and where it's from at times.

123
00:06:09,430 --> 00:06:10,850
But, it doesn't do anything else.

124
00:06:10,850 --> 00:06:13,820
So, when you actually have something
like that, it really does work.

125
00:06:13,820 --> 00:06:16,370
Our ACLs simply kind of do that thing.

126
00:06:16,370 --> 00:06:20,750
But, at the same time, it doesn't work
as efficiently as it needs to, nor

127
00:06:20,750 --> 00:06:22,280
as well as it can.

128
00:06:22,280 --> 00:06:25,370
Besides the idea of the staple.

129
00:06:25,370 --> 00:06:26,685
I couldn't remember what I was gonna say.

130
00:06:26,685 --> 00:06:27,720
[LAUGH]
>> And you know Ronnie,

131
00:06:27,720 --> 00:06:28,340
you mentioned ACLs.

132
00:06:28,340 --> 00:06:31,740
For those of you that have already watched
the ACL episode, which I think was two or

133
00:06:31,740 --> 00:06:33,280
three episodes ago.

134
00:06:33,280 --> 00:06:38,080
We talked about ACLs and
how you can use them as a firewall.

135
00:06:38,080 --> 00:06:41,510
But they had that big glaring
problem that they don't track state.

136
00:06:41,510 --> 00:06:43,660
So let me just bring up this diagram here.

137
00:06:43,660 --> 00:06:50,050
A packet firewall is simply a firewall
that is looking at packets and based

138
00:06:50,050 --> 00:06:54,530
on the merit of that one packet, deciding
wether it should get through or not.

139
00:06:54,530 --> 00:06:57,740
A staple firewall is one
that looks at a packet and

140
00:06:57,740 --> 00:07:00,440
based not just on the merits
of that one packet.

141
00:07:00,440 --> 00:07:04,980
But the conversation tied around that
packet whether or not we allow it through.

142
00:07:04,980 --> 00:07:05,550
All right.

143
00:07:05,550 --> 00:07:09,950
So an example would be like if I'm using,
let's say I'm using routers okay.

144
00:07:09,950 --> 00:07:12,150
So I'm using these routers right here.

145
00:07:12,150 --> 00:07:19,040
And I have a ACL applied on router A and
I've got this ACL applied right here.

146
00:07:19,040 --> 00:07:24,310
And I basically say that
anybody on my inside network

147
00:07:24,310 --> 00:07:26,160
is allowed to get out to the Internet.

148
00:07:26,160 --> 00:07:30,770
So, somebody here on the private network
is allowed to get out to the Internet.

149
00:07:30,770 --> 00:07:34,910
But, then nobody on the Internet
is allowed to get back in, right?

150
00:07:34,910 --> 00:07:37,930
We don't want anybody on the Internet
getting inside my network.

151
00:07:37,930 --> 00:07:41,290
Well the problem is when somebody
from the private network goes out,

152
00:07:41,290 --> 00:07:44,880
that host on the outside has to reply.

153
00:07:44,880 --> 00:07:49,970
And if I'm just doing a packet firewall,
when that reply comes back.

154
00:07:49,970 --> 00:07:53,375
Its gonna get blocked,
it's not gonna be allowed to pass through.

155
00:07:53,375 --> 00:07:54,847
We're never gonna get the reply,

156
00:07:54,847 --> 00:07:58,675
communications are effectively broken cuz
we create a unidirectional communication.

157
00:07:58,675 --> 00:07:59,545
>> Right.

158
00:07:59,545 --> 00:08:03,545
>> So, in a packet firewall you
have to create two sets of rules.

159
00:08:03,545 --> 00:08:07,585
One set of rules for outgoing traffic and
another set of rules for incoming traffic.

160
00:08:07,585 --> 00:08:09,875
You gotta do your work twice.

161
00:08:09,875 --> 00:08:13,853
A stateful firewall,
on the other hand, says, all right,

162
00:08:13,853 --> 00:08:18,221
I'm not gonna allow anybody from
the internet to come back in, but

163
00:08:18,221 --> 00:08:22,901
when it sees this connection from our
private LAN go out to the outside,

164
00:08:22,901 --> 00:08:27,360
when it sees that happen,
It expects a reply to come back.

165
00:08:27,360 --> 00:08:30,530
And it matches that reply with
the communication that went out in

166
00:08:30,530 --> 00:08:31,180
the first place.

167
00:08:31,180 --> 00:08:34,510
And it says, oh, this is a reply
to something I allowed earlier.

168
00:08:34,510 --> 00:08:36,520
I'll let it pass through.

169
00:08:36,520 --> 00:08:41,080
And it does that by tracking the state
of every communication we make.

170
00:08:41,080 --> 00:08:42,200
We open a state.

171
00:08:42,200 --> 00:08:43,820
We open a session when we reach out.

172
00:08:43,820 --> 00:08:47,260
And the firewall will automatically
allow the replies to it.

173
00:08:47,260 --> 00:08:49,050
>> Yeah.
And this really helps us because it

174
00:08:49,050 --> 00:08:51,140
means also from the outside
on the internet, right?

175
00:08:51,140 --> 00:08:52,930
If traffic originates from out there,

176
00:08:52,930 --> 00:08:56,110
we don't have to set up another
default rule to block it.

177
00:08:57,480 --> 00:09:01,130
As long as it actually came from
the inside out then we're okay.

178
00:09:01,130 --> 00:09:04,930
If it starts from the outside going in,
then it blocks it for us and

179
00:09:04,930 --> 00:09:06,490
again much more efficient.

180
00:09:06,490 --> 00:09:09,370
It helps us out with again not
having to configure as many rules.

181
00:09:09,370 --> 00:09:11,820
So, less administrative effort overall.

182
00:09:11,820 --> 00:09:12,460
>> Yeah.

183
00:09:12,460 --> 00:09:15,040
Absolutely, and
it's pretty much a given these days.

184
00:09:15,040 --> 00:09:15,760
>> Yeah.
>> That if you're going

185
00:09:15,760 --> 00:09:18,510
implement a firewall it's going
to be a stateful firewall.

186
00:09:18,510 --> 00:09:23,965
But if you're trying to force a Cisco
router to be a firewall using just

187
00:09:23,965 --> 00:09:29,740
ACLs you're effectively a packet
filter and not a stateful firewall.

188
00:09:29,740 --> 00:09:32,760
And it can work, but
it does take a lot of juggling.

189
00:09:32,760 --> 00:09:35,010
There's a lot of tricky
protocols out there.

190
00:09:35,010 --> 00:09:38,510
Some protocols that start as TCP and
flip to UDP and so on,

191
00:09:38,510 --> 00:09:41,700
it's really difficult to write
the rules to be able to match that.

192
00:09:41,700 --> 00:09:43,620
FTP is a particular challenge.

193
00:09:43,620 --> 00:09:44,810
DNS can be.

194
00:09:44,810 --> 00:09:48,480
There's some other protocols too
that we have to really tweak and

195
00:09:48,480 --> 00:09:50,620
work with to get them going smooth.

196
00:09:50,620 --> 00:09:51,120
>> Right.

197
00:09:52,160 --> 00:09:57,000
All right, so that takes care of proxy and
packet and stateful firewalls.

198
00:09:57,000 --> 00:09:57,860
What's next on the list?

199
00:09:57,860 --> 00:09:59,870
>> It looks like
application firewalls here.

200
00:09:59,870 --> 00:10:01,020
>> Application firewalls.

201
00:10:01,020 --> 00:10:07,270
Now, I mentioned that certain
protocols like FTP are pretty tricky.

202
00:10:07,270 --> 00:10:13,180
That, when they go out, like FTP will
build a session using TCP on port 21.

203
00:10:13,180 --> 00:10:16,930
But when it goes to transfer a file,
a lot of times it uses passive mode, and

204
00:10:16,930 --> 00:10:21,000
it'll do UDP transfers
on a random port number.

205
00:10:21,000 --> 00:10:22,282
We don't know what.

206
00:10:22,282 --> 00:10:23,020
Okay.
So

207
00:10:23,020 --> 00:10:24,660
really frustrating to be able to try and

208
00:10:24,660 --> 00:10:29,480
allow that through a firewall if you
don't know what port it's going to pick.

209
00:10:29,480 --> 00:10:32,160
So a application gateway.

210
00:10:32,160 --> 00:10:33,990
There's a few different terms here, right.

episodes.description: An intrusion prevention system is a device that monitors traffic, looks at the traffic patterns and analyzes it to determine whether or not an attack is happening. Viewers will hear discussions of the use of Cisco Intrusion Prevention Systems (IPS) as a security implementation in the network, the most common implementations as well as configuring the Cisco IOS IPS using the CCP.
